member.name: T:WolfCurses.ITick
member.summary: Used by simulation and all attached modes and their states. Allows them to receive ticks and understand the difference between a system tick that occurs unpredictably and a simulation tick which occurs at fixed intervals based on the tick delta of incoming system ticks adding up to whatever constant is set in the core simulation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.ITick.OnTick(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called when the simulation is ticked by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. Each of these system ticks is called at unpredictable rates, however if not a system tick that means the simulation has processed enough of them to fire off event for fixed interval that is set in the core simulation by constant in milliseconds.
member.param: TRUE if ticked unpredictably by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. FALSE if pulsed by game simulation at fixed interval.
Determines if the simulation has force ticked without advancing time or down the trail. Used by special events that want to simulate passage of time without actually any actual time moving by.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.SimulationApp
member.summary: Base simulation application class object. This class should not be declared directly but inherited by actual instance of game controller.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.SHOW_COMMANDS
member.summary: Determines if the dynamic menu system should show the command names or only numbers. If false then only numbers will be shown.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.TICK_INTERVAL
member.summary: Constant for the amount of time difference that should occur from last tick and current tick in milliseconds before the simulation logic will be ticked.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.SimulationApp._currentTickTime
member.summary: Time and date of latest system tick, used to measure total elapsed time and tick simulation after each second.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.SimulationApp._lastTickTime
member.summary: Last known time the simulation was ticked with logic and all sub-systems. This is not the same as a system tick which can happen hundreds of thousands of times a second or just a few, we only measure the difference in time on them.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.SimulationApp._spinningPixel
member.summary: Spinning character pixel.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.IsClosing
member.summary: Determines if the simulation is currently closing down.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.TickPhase
member.summary: Shows the current status of the simulation visually as a spinning glyph, the purpose of which is to show that there is no hang in the simulation or logic controllers and everything is moving along and waiting for input or displaying something to user.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.TotalSecondsTicked
member.summary: Total number of ticks that have gone by from measuring system ticks, this means this measures the total number of seconds that have gone by using the pulses and time dilation without the use of dirty times that spawn more threads.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.Random
member.summary: Used for rolling the virtual dice in the simulation to determine the outcome of various events.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.WindowManager
member.summary: Keeps track of the currently attached game Windows, which one is active, and getting text user interface data.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.InputManager
member.summary: Handles input from the users keyboard, holds an input buffer and will push it to the simulation when return key is pressed.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.SceneGraph
member.summary: Shows the current state of the simulation as text only interface (TUI). Uses default constants if the attached Windows or state does not override this functionality and it is ticked.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.AllowedWindows
member.summary: Determines what windows the simulation will be capable of using and creating using the window managers factory.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.OnTick(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called when the simulation is ticked by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. Each of these system ticks is called at unpredictable rates, however if not a system tick that means the simulation has processed enough of them to fire off event for fixed interval that is set in the core simulation by constant in milliseconds.
member.param: TRUE if ticked unpredictably by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. FALSE if pulsed by game simulation at fixed interval.
Determines if the simulation has force ticked without advancing time or down the trail. Used by special events that want to simulate passage of time without actually any actual time moving by.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.OnFirstTick
member.summary: Fired when the ticker receives the first system tick event.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.Destroy
member.summary: Fired when the simulation is closing and needs to clear out any data structures that it created so the program can exit cleanly.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.Restart
member.summary: Creates and or clears data sets required for game simulation and attaches the travel menu and the main menu to make the program completely restarted as if fresh.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.OnPreDestroy
member.summary: Called when simulation is about to destroy itself, but right before it actually does it.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.SimulationApp.OnPreRender
member.summary: Called by the text user interface scene graph renderer before it asks the active window to render itself out for display.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager
member.summary: Deals with keep track of input to the simulation via whatever form that may end up taking. The default implementation is a text user interface (TUI) which allows for the currently accepted commands to be seen and only then accepted.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.PRESSENTER
member.summary: Holds a constant representation of the string telling the user to press enter key to continue so we don't repeat ourselves.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager._simUnit
member.summary: Reference to simulation that is controlling the input manager.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager._commandQueue
member.summary: Holds a series of commands that need to be executed in the order they come out of the collection.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.#ctor(WolfCurses.SimulationApp)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Core simulation which is controlling the window manager.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.InputBuffer
member.summary: Input buffer that we will use to hold characters until need to send them to simulation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.Destroy
member.summary: Fired when the simulation is closing and needs to clear out any data structures that it created so the program can exit cleanly.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.OnTick(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called when the simulation is ticked by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. Each of these system ticks is called at unpredictable rates, however if not a system tick that means the simulation has processed enough of them to fire off event for fixed interval that is set in the core simulation by constant in milliseconds.
member.param: TRUE if ticked unpredictably by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. FALSE if pulsed by game simulation at fixed interval.
Determines if the simulation has force ticked without advancing time or down the trail. Used by special events that want to simulate passage of time without actually any actual time moving by.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.SendInputBufferAsCommand
member.summary: Clears the input buffer and submits whatever was in there to the simulation for processing. Implementation is left up the game simulation itself entirely.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.OnCharacterAddedToInputBuffer(System.String)
member.summary: Fired when the simulation receives an individual character from then input system. Depending on what it is we will do something, or not!
member.param: String character converted into a string representation of itself.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.AddCharToInputBuffer(System.Char)
member.summary: Populates an internal input buffer for the simulation that is used to eventually return a possible command string to active game Windows.
member.param: The key Char.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.RemoveLastCharOfInputBuffer
member.summary: Removes the last character from input buffer if greater than zero.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.AddCommandToQueue(System.String)
member.summary: Fired by messaging system or user interface that wants to interact with the simulation by sending string command that should be able to be parsed into a valid command that can be run on the current game Windows.
member.param: Passed in command from controller, text was trimmed but nothing more.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.InputManager.ClearBuffer
member.summary: Removes any text data from the input buffer resetting it to an empty string again.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer
member.summary: Used for rolling the virtual dice in the simulation to determine the outcome of various events.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer._random
member.summary: Game logic objects.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.RandomSeed
member.summary: Number used to seed the random number generator.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.Destroy
member.summary: Fired when the simulation is closing and needs to clear out any data structures that it created so the program can exit cleanly.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.Next
member.summary: C64 style RND with 0 would return clock timer 0 - 60 number so we do the same here for simulation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.Next(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a random number within a specified range.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to and less than ; that is, the range of return values includes but not . If equals , is returned.
member.param: The inclusive lower bound of the random number returned.
The exclusive upper bound of the random number returned. must be greater than or equal to .

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.Next(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns a nonnegative random number less than the specified maximum.
member.returns: A 32-bit signed integer greater than or equal to zero, and less than ; that is, the range of return values ordinarily includes zero but not . However, if equals zero, is returned.
member.param: The exclusive upper bound of the random number to be generated. must be greater than or equal to zero.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.NextDouble
member.summary: Returns a random number between 0.0 and 1.0.
member.returns: A double-precision floating point number greater than or equal to 0.0, and less than 1.0.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.NextBytes(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Fills the elements of a specified array of bytes with random numbers.
member.param: An array of bytes to contain random numbers.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.Randomizer.NextBool
member.summary: Returns a random Boolean value.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph
member.summary: Provides base functionality for rendering out the simulation state via text user interface (TUI). This class has no idea about how other modules work and only serves to query them for string data which will be compiled into a console only view of the simulation which is intended to be the lowest level of visualization but theoretically anything could be a renderer for the simulation.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.ScreenBufferDirty
member.summary: Fired when the screen back buffer has changed from what is currently being shown, this forces a redraw.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.GAMEMODE_DEFAULT_TUI
member.summary: Default string used when game Windows has nothing better to say.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.GAMEMODE_EMPTY_TUI
member.summary: Default string used when there are no game modes at all.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph._simUnit
member.summary: Reference to simulation that is controlling the text user interface and actually filling the screen buffer with data.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.#ctor(WolfCurses.SimulationApp)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Core simulation which is controlling the window manager.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.ScreenBuffer
member.summary: Holds the last known representation of the game simulation and current Windows text user interface, only pushes update when a change occurs.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.Destroy
member.summary: Fired when the simulation is closing and needs to clear out any data structures that it created so the program can exit cleanly.

Each of these system ticks is called at unpredictable rates, however if not a system tick that means the simulation has processed enough of them to fire off event for fixed interval that is set in the core simulation by constant in milliseconds.

Determines if the simulation has force ticked without advancing time or down the trail. Used by special events that want to simulate passage of time without actually any actual time moving by.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.SceneGraph.OnRender

member.summary: Fired when the screen back buffer has changed from what is currently being shown, this forces a redraw.

member.summary: Removes any and all data from the text user interface renderer.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager
member.summary: Builds up a list of game modes and their states using reflection and attributes. Contains methods to add game modes to running simulation. Can also remove modes and modify them further with states.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.formFactory
member.summary: Keeps track of all the possible states a given game mode can have by using attributes and reflection to keep track of which user data object gets mapped to which particular state.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.windowFactory
member.summary: Factory pattern that will create game modes for it based on attribute at the top of each one that defines what window type it is responsible for.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.windowList
member.summary: Current list of all game modes, only the last one added gets ticked this is so game modes can attach things on-top of themselves like stores and trades.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.#ctor(WolfCurses.SimulationApp)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Core simulation which is controlling the window manager.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.FocusedWindow
member.summary: References the current active game Windows, or the last attached game Windows in the simulation.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.Count
member.summary: Retrieves the total number of windows that the manager is currently handling.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.AcceptingInput
member.summary: Determines if this simulation is currently accepting input at all, the conditions for this require some game Windows to be attached and or active move to not be null.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.Destroy
member.summary: Fired when the simulation is closing and needs to clear out any data structures that it created so the program can exit cleanly.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.CreateStateFromType(WolfCurses.Window.IWindow,System.Type)

The state Type.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.CleanWindows
member.summary: Removes any and all inactive game modes that need to be removed from the simulation.
member.returns: TRUE if modes were removes, changing the active Windows or nulling it. FALSE if nothing changed because nothing was removed or no modes.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.OnWindowAdded
member.summary: Tell all the other game modes that we added another Windows.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.Add(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates and adds the specified game Windows to the simulation if it does not already exist in the list of modes.
member.param: Enumeration value of the Windows which should be created.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Core.WindowManager.Clear
member.summary: Removes every window and form from the simulation and makes it a blank slate. Use with caution, if there is an operation in progress, or waiting for user input this will not respect that and just forcefully destroy everything.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.ArrayExtensions.TrueCount(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Boolean})
member.summary: Determines the count of boolean values in an array that are true. Intended to be used in conjunction with count to determine if all are true for a entire sequence.
member.param: Array of bool.
member.returns: Number of bool values in array that were true.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.ArrayExtensions.ClosestTo(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Int32},System.Int32)
member.summary: NB Method will return int. MaxValue for a sequence containing no elements. Intended to be used to match int value to enumeration but without directly casting it, instead looking for closest match to target value.
member.param: Enumerable collection of integers that make up our collection.
Target value which needs to be compared against collection values.
member.returns: Int closest matching in collection to target value.

member.summary: Find all the classes which have a custom attribute I've defined on them, and I want to be able to find them on-the-fly when an application is using my library.

member.summary: Determine if a type implements a specific generic interface type.

member.param: Object that will have attribute tag specified in generic parameter..
member.returns: Attribute of the specified type from inputted object.

member.summary: Attempts to grab description attribute from any object.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions
member.summary: Helper class that deals with activating classes without using the actual activator class because that requires and empty parameterless constructor and we cannot always guarantee we will be able have one. Using these methods don't require a constructor to be used and furthermore the use of expressions to generate them ensures caching so penalty for type activation is only hit once on first instance creation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions.HasDefaultConstructor(System.Type)
member.summary: FormatterServices.GetUninitializedObject(t) will fail for string. Hence special handling for string is in place to return empty string.
member.param: The t.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions.New`1
member.summary: Create expression is effectively cached and incurs penalty only the first time the type is loaded. Will handle value types too in an efficient manner.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions.New`1.Instance
member.summary: The instance.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions.New`1.Creator
member.summary: The creator.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions.New`1.GetUninitializedObject(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the specified type, bypassing the constructor.
member.param: The type to create
member.exception: If the platform does not support constructor-skipping

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.FactoryExtensions.New`1.TryGetUninitializedObjectWithFormatterServices(System.Type)
member.summary: Manually calls the private method which Microsoft has not marked as public yet.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Utility.StringExtensions
member.summary: Utility class that contains useful extension methods that make working with strings a little easier and less repetitive.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.StringExtensions.Truncate(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Cuts off a string given a certain input amount, useful for ensuring the user never enters more than possible into a given field.
member.param: String that needs to be truncated to max length.
Negative values will cause exception.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.StringExtensions.WordWrap(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Word wraps the given text to fit within the specified width.
member.param: Text to be word wrapped
Width, in characters, to which the text should be word wrapped

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Utility.StringExtensions.BreakLine(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Locates position to break the given line so as to avoid breaking words.
member.param: String that contains line of text
Index where line of text starts
Maximum line length

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow
member.summary: Underlying game Windows interface, used by base simulation to keep track of what data should currently have control over the simulation details. Only top most game Windows will ever be ticked.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.ShouldRemoveMode
member.summary: Determines if the game Windows should not be ticked if it is active but instead removed. The Windows when set to being removed will not actually be removed until the simulation attempts to tick it and realizes that this is set to true and then it will be removed.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.AcceptsInput
member.summary: Determines if user input is currently allowed to be typed and filled into the input buffer.
member.remarks: Default is FALSE. Setting to TRUE allows characters and input buffer to be read when submitted.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.CurrentForm
member.summary: Holds the current state which this Windows is in, a Windows will cycle through available states until it is finished and then detach.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.UserData
member.summary: Intended to be overridden in abstract class by generics to provide method to return object that contains all the data for parent game Windows.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.SetForm(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates and adds the specified type of state to currently active game Windows.
member.param: The state Type.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.ClearForm
member.summary: Removes the current state from the active game Windows.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.RemoveWindowNextTick
member.summary: Sets the flag for this game Windows to be removed the next time it is ticked by the simulation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.OnRenderWindow
member.summary: Grabs the text user interface string that will be used for debugging on console application.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.SendCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Intended to be used by base simulation to pass along the input buffer after the user has typed several characters into the input buffer. This is used when allowing the user to input custom strings like names for their party members.
member.param: The input.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.OnWindowPostCreate
member.summary: Called after the Windows has been added to list of modes and made active.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.OnWindowActivate
member.summary: Called when the Windows manager in simulation makes this Windows the currently active game Windows. Depending on order of modes this might not get called until the Windows is actually ticked by the simulation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.IWindow.OnWindowAdded
member.summary: Fired when the simulation adds a game Windows that is not this Windows. Used to execute code in other modes that are not the active Windows anymore one last time.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2
member.summary: Facilitates the ability to control the entire simulation with the passes interface reference. Server simulation keeps track of all currently loaded game modes and will only tick the top-most one so they can be stacked and clear out until there are none.
member.typeparam: Enumeration of all the available commands this window supports.
Window data class that will be used for this window.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._simUnit
member.summary: Reference to simulation core which houses the window manager and other core modules.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuActions
member.summary: Reference for mappings to go from enumeration value to action.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuChoiceCount
member.summary: Keeps track of the total number of menu choices that are currently available to this window.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuCommands
member.summary: Reference to all of the possible commands that this game Windows supports routing back to the game simulation that spawned it.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuFooter
member.summary: Holds the footer text that we will place below menu but before input buffer text.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuHeader
member.summary: Holds the prefix text that can go above the menu text if it exists.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuMappings
member.summary: Reference for mappings to go from string data into a valid loaded input enumeration value.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2._menuPrompt
member.summary: Holds the text user interface data that we are going to eventually render out to the user.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.#ctor(WolfCurses.SimulationApp)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: Core simulation which is controlling the form factory.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.Form
member.summary: Current game Windows state that is being ticked when this Windows is ticked by the underlying simulation.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.MenuHeader
member.summary: Defines the text prefix which will go above the menu, used to show any useful information the game Windows might need to at the top of menu selections.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.MenuFooter
member.summary: Similar to the header this will define some text that should go below the menu selection but before the user input field.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.ShowCommandNamesInMenu
member.summary: Determines if the input names for the particular action should be printed out alongside the number the user can press to control that particular enum.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.UserData
member.summary: Intended to be overridden in abstract class by generics to provide method to return object that contains all the data for parent game Windows.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.Commands
member.summary: Because of how generics work in C# we need to have the ability to override a method in implementing classes to get back the correct commands for the implementation from abstract class inheritance chain. On the bright side it enforces the commands returned to be of the specified enum in generics.
member.returns: Formatting list of enumeration values that can be iterated over as array.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.WolfCurses#Window#IWindow#UserData
member.summary: Intended to be overridden in abstract class by generics to provide method to return object that contains all the data for parent game Windows.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.ShouldRemoveMode
member.summary: Determines if the game Windows should not be ticked if it is active but instead removed. The Windows when set to being removed will not actually be removed until the simulation attempts to tick it and realizes that this is set to true and then it will be removed.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.RemoveWindowNextTick
member.summary: Sets the flag for this game Windows to be removed the next time it is ticked by the simulation.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.AcceptsInput
member.summary: Determines if user input is currently allowed to be typed and filled into the input buffer.
member.remarks: Default is FALSE. Setting to TRUE allows characters and input buffer to be read when submitted.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.CurrentForm
member.summary: Holds the current state which this Windows is in, a Windows will cycle through available states until it is finished and then detach.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.ClearForm
member.summary: Removes the current state from the active game Windows.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnRenderWindow
member.summary: Fired by simulation when it wants to request latest text user interface data for the game Windows, this is used to display to user console specific information about what the simulation wants.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.SendCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Fired by messaging system or user interface that wants to interact with the simulation by sending string input that should be able to be parsed into a valid input that can be run on the current game Windows.
member.param: Passed in input from controller, text was trimmed but nothing more.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnWindowPostCreate
member.summary: Called after the Windows has been added to list of modes and made active.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnWindowActivate
member.summary: Called when the Windows manager in simulation makes this Windows the currently active game Windows. Depending on order of modes this might not get called until the Windows is actually ticked by the simulation.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnWindowAdded
member.summary: Fired when the simulation adds a game Windows that is not this Windows. Used to execute code in other modes that are not the active Windows anymore one last time.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.Compare(WolfCurses.Window.IWindow,WolfCurses.Window.IWindow)
member.summary: The compare.
member.param: The x.
The y.

member.summary: The compare to.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.SetForm(System.Type)
member.summary: Creates and adds the specified type of state to currently active game Windows.
member.param: The state Type.
member.remarks: If Windows does not support given state, an argument exception will be thrown!

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnTick(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Called when the simulation is ticked by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. Each of these system ticks is called at unpredictable rates, however if not a system tick that means the simulation has processed enough of them to fire off event for fixed interval that is set in the core simulation by constant in milliseconds.
member.param: TRUE if ticked unpredictably by underlying operating system, game engine, or potato. FALSE if pulsed by game simulation at fixed interval.
Determines if the simulation has force ticked without advancing time or down the trail. Used by special events that want to simulate passage of time without actually any actual time moving by.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnFormChange
member.summary: Allows underlying parent game Windows to the state understand it changed.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.AddCommand(System.Action,`0,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new game Windows menu selection that will be available to send as a input for this specific game Windows.
member.param: Method that will be run when the choice is made.
Associated input that will trigger the respective action in the active game Windows.
Text that will be shown to user so they know what the choice means.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.RefreshCommandMappings
member.summary: Recalculates all of the commands mappings giving them a clear path from a string input

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.AddCommand(System.Action,`0)
member.summary: Adds a new game menu selection with description pulled from attribute on input enumeration. This override is not meant for menu selections where you want to manually specify the description of the menu item, this way it will be pulled from enum description attribute.
member.param: Method that will be run when the choice is made.
Associated input that will trigger the respective action in the active game Windows.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.ClearCommands
member.summary: Forces the menu choices to be cleared out, this is used by modes like the store to refresh the data shown in the menu to match purchasing decisions.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Window`2.OnModeRemoved
member.summary: Fired when this game Windows is removed from the list of available and ticked modes in the simulation.

member.summary: The get hash code.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.WindowData
member.summary: Used to make sure that every Windows info class has a basic data structure that we can rely on for creating it via Windows factory.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.WindowFactory
member.summary: Factory pattern for creating game modes on the fly during runtime based on enumeration input parameter.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.WindowFactory._simUnit
member.summary: Reference to running game simulation we will need to pass along to created window instances.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.WindowFactory.#ctor(WolfCurses.SimulationApp)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. Creates a new Windows factory that will look over the application for all known game types and create reference list which we can use to get instances of a given Windows by asking for it.
member.param: Core simulation which is controlling the window factory.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.WindowFactory.Windows
member.summary: Reference dictionary for all the found game modes that have the game Windows attribute on top of them which the simulation will want to be able to create instances of when running.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.WindowFactory.CreateWindow(System.Type)
member.summary: Change to new view Windows when told that internal logic wants to display view options to player for a specific set of data in the simulation.
member.param: The windows.
member.returns: New game Windows instance based on the Windows input parameter.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.WindowFactory.Destroy
member.summary: Called when the simulation is closing down.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Form`1.AllowInput
member.summary: Determines if this dialog state is allowed to receive any input at all, even empty line returns. This is useful for preventing the player from leaving a particular dialog until you are ready or finished processing some data.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Form`1.OnRenderForm
member.summary: Returns a text only representation of the current game Windows state. Could be a statement, information, question waiting input, etc.

member.summary: Fired when the game Windows current state is not null and input buffer does not match any known command.
member.param: Contents of the input buffer which didn't match any known command in parent game Windows.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Form`1.OnFormPostCreate
member.summary: Fired after the state has been completely attached to the simulation letting the state know it can browse the user data and other properties below it.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Form`1.OnFormActivate
member.summary: Fired when the window is activated and or refocused after another window was removed from being on-top of it. Useful for re-initializing form data after something like a random event runs which might kill people or alter the vehicle inventory.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.summary: Reference dictionary for all the reflected state types.

member.summary: Creates and adds the specified type of state to currently active game Windows.

Current active game Windows passed to factory so no need to call game simulation singleton.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Form.IForm
member.summary: Defines interface for game mode state which can show data, accept input, add new game modes, set new state, and have user data custom per implementation.

member.summary: Intended to be overridden in abstract class by generics to provide method to return object that contains all the data for parent game Windows.

member.summary: Fired when the window is activated and or refocused after another window was removed from being on-top of it. Useful for re-initializing form data after something like a random event runs which might kill people or alter the vehicle inventory.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Form.ParentWindowAttribute
member.summary: Used to map game Windows states to their respective parent modes by Windows type enumeration value. All of this is done by the state factory which is called by the base simulation whom also keeps track of all the game modes in similar manner. After startup we will add to that data by telling what possible states may exist for a particular game Windows and what user data IModeInfo object will be created.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.ParentWindowAttribute.#ctor(System.Type)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The parent Window.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Form.ParentWindowAttribute.ParentWindow
member.summary: Defines what the parent game mode of this particular state should be.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogResponse
member.summary: Used by game Windows state prefab to determine what the response was to a particular dialog prompt.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogResponse.No
member.summary: User indicated their reply to the prompt was NO in one form or another.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogResponse.Yes
member.summary: User indicated their reply to the prompt was YES in one form or another.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogResponse.Custom
member.summary: No response was given, only a blank command meaning the user is trying to continue.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogType
member.summary: Determines what type of dialog this will be, as in should it just display a message and wait for any input before firing response method.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogType.Prompt
member.summary: Dialog will only display the message prompt and not ask for any input and instead ask the user to press RETURN KEY to continue. Used when you need to just tell the user something like a pop-up.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogType.YesNo
member.summary: Dialog will accept only YES or NO answer and nothing else, if the user enters invalid data then it will be ignored until a valid response is given by the user.c

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogType.Custom
member.summary: Dialog will accept either YES or NO response, if neither are received then it will process it as a cancel or continue method. Up to implementation to deal with it at this point.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1
member.summary: Represents a dialog box that acts like a pop-up where it displays some piece of data, accepts any key for input and then closes.
member.typeparam: Windows information object that will be applied to this state on when constructor is called.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1._prompt
member.summary: Reference for all the text we will display for user to read when the state is activated.

member.name: F:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1._seenPrompt
member.summary: Keeps track if the player is done looking at this dialog prompt.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1.#ctor(WolfCurses.Window.IWindow)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class. This constructor will be used by the other one
member.param: The window.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1.DialogType
member.summary: Defines what type of dialog this will act like depending on this enumeration value. Up to implementation to define desired behavior.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1.InputFillsBuffer
member.summary: Determines if user input is currently allowed to be typed and filled into the input buffer.
member.remarks: Default is FALSE. Setting to TRUE allows characters and input buffer to be read when submitted.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1.OnFormPostCreate
member.summary: Fired after the state has been completely attached to the simulation letting the state know it can browse the user data and other properties below it.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1.OnDialogPrompt

member.summary: Returns a text only representation of the current game Windows state. Could be a statement, information, question waiting input, etc.

member.name: M:WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.InputForm`1.OnDialogResponse(WolfCurses.Window.Form.Input.DialogResponse)
member.summary: Fired when the dialog receives favorable input and determines a response based on this. From this method it is common to attach another state, or remove the current state based on the response.
member.param: The response the dialog parsed from simulation input buffer.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Menu.IMenuChoice`1
member.summary: Defines a choice in the dynamic action selection system for a given game Windows. This is intended to be used by a wrapper for menu choices that aggregates all of the possible actions a given game Windows can make while it is active in the simulation.

member.name: P:WolfCurses.Window.Menu.IMenuChoice`1.Command
member.summary: Gets or sets the command.

member.name: T:WolfCurses.Window.Menu.MenuChoice`1
member.summary: Defines a choice in the dynamic action selection system for a given game mode. This is intended to be used by a wrapper for menu choices that aggregates all of the possible actions a given game mode can make while it is active in the simulation.
